Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2013
Award.AbstractNarration:
The phylogenomics of diet breadth in heliothine moths

The evolution of diet breadth amongst herbivorous insects has long served as a testing ground for hypotheses about the role of ecological adaptation in biological diversification and speciation, but the scope of such research has been limited by the tools available. The advent of next generation sequencing technologies has made it possible to conduct a detailed examination of diet breadth evolution in a well-researched group of moths (Lepidoptera: Noctuidae: Heliothinae). The family Noctuidae is one of the largest in the order Lepidoptera, and research on the noctuid subfamily Heliothinae, which includes some of the world's most injurious crop pests, spans a wide range of evolutionary questions. This research project will use comparative genomics to examine the genetic basis of host plant range in at least seven heliothine species (ranging from extreme generalists feeding on many plant orders to extreme specialists feeding on a few plant species in a single genus) to identify the genes/gene categories involved in diet breadth evolution. By placing these results in a phylogenetic context, this research will help clarify the role of diet breadth evolution in the extraordinary phylogenetic radiation of the Lepidoptera.

This project will provide the Fellow with expertise in the emerging field of phylogenomics, and with fundamental training in bioinformatics, genomics, and transcriptomics. These skills will allow the Fellow to pursue future research on the genetic basis of ecologically important traits in a variety of organisms. The approaches developed during the course of this research will contribute to the analysis of genomic data from non-model organisms, and will potentially provide new techniques for integrating analyses at different levels (e.g., populations, species, and higher taxa). This project includes participation by middle school, high school, and college students from underrepresented groups, who will be mentored in the theory and practice of scientific research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research accomplishments

At AMNH:

  • To understand the genes involved in determining whether an herbivorous insect is a generalist (and thus likely to be a pest) or a specialist, I generated transcriptomes for Heliothis virescens and Heliothis subflexa, closely related, hybridizable, North American heliothine moths with divergent host plant ranges. I generated transcriptomes for multiple tissues (adult antennae, heads, legs, and thoraxes; larval heads and midguts) from each species and sex. The results of this study could lead to actionable genetic targets for controlling H. virescens.
  • To understand how a generalist species such as H. virescens can feed on diverse host plants with very different defenses, I generated transcriptomes from the digestive tracts of caterpillars feeding on 8 different plant species. Each plant has a different chemical defense profile, and my goal was to identify the specific genes whose expression allow H. virescens to cope with varied plant defenses. The results of this study could lead to safer pest control strategies.
  • To understand how rapidly host plant range can evolve, I made progress toward a molecular phylogeny of rare Heliothine moths using “ancient” DNA. Using material I collected during my Fulbright Scholar visit to Brazil, I am generating the first molecular phylogeny for a species complex that is of great economic importance in North and South America. Because some members of the species group are very difficult to collect, I have developed specialized protocols for the extraction and sequencing of DNA from single legs of specimens up to 150 years old.

Collaborations:

  • With Jeff Rosenfeld (Rutgers University): Comparative genomics of mosquito genomes to look for enriched functional categories involved in the transmission of Zika virus (Culicid mosquitos) and falciparum malaria (Anopheline mosquitos).
  • With Wiebke Feindt (visiting scholar from Germany): assembly and comparison of transcriptomes from several species of Megaloprepus (giant damselflies).
  • With Paul Goldstein (USDA/Smithsonian): assembly and comparison of transcriptomes from North American Noctuoids to determine phylogenetic relationships and the evolution of host plant associations.
  • With collaborators at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratories, Pacific Biosciences long read sequencing of the Heliothis virescens genome.

Fieldwork:

  • I spent four months in Northeastern Brazil collecting heliothine moths and caterpillars. In collaboration with Brazilian scientists and students, I explored the Atlantic Coastal Rain Forest (Bahia), agricultural regions (Goias and Brasilia), and high chaparral (Northern Goias). I collected material from 5 species for which no molecular data exist, and am using these to build a molecular phylogeny of the virescens group.

 

Broader impacts

  • Mentored 6 NYC high school students through AMNH’s Student Research Mentoring Program (August-July each year).
  • Mentored a female minority student for two years. She was recently accepted to her first choice college, where she will study Biology.
  • Mentored a female community college student through NSF’s Research Experiences for Undergraduates.
  • Mentored two Brazilian graduate students in molecular biology    techniques over their 4-month visit to AMNH. These were students I worked with in Brazil, and their visit represents an ongoing collaboration with Brazilian scientists.
  • Served for 2 years as a STEM mentor to 4th and 5th graders at a local Elementary school.
  • Serve as science leader to a mixed troop of Brownies and Girl Scouts (ages 7-14).
  • Instructor for the RGGS class “Laboratory Techniques for Next-Generation Sequencing.”

 Presentations and publications

  • Presented session keynote address at the annual meeting of The Society for Experimental Biology (Brighton, UK). Title: Comparative genomic approaches to determining gene function in non-model organisms: Goldilocks or Procrustes?
  • Presentation at RGGS Comparative Biology seminar series. Title: Pushing the limits of electronic annotation: A case study with Anopheline vectors of P. falciparum.
  • Attended the Gordon Research Conference on Ecological and Evolutionary Genomics (Maine, US). Presented poster, “Using genomics to understand host plant use.”
  • Attended the meeting "Biology of Genomes" at Cold Spring Harbor.  Presented poster,  "From just-so stories to genes."
  • Rosenfeld, J., Oppenheim, S., and DeSalle, R (2016). A whole genome gene content phylogenetic analysis of anopheline mosquitoes. Molecular Phylogeny and Evolution. Published.
  • Sara Oppenheim, Richard H. Baker, Sabrina Simon, and Rob DeSalle (2014). We can’t all be supermodels: The value of comparative transcriptomics to the study of non-model insects. Insect Molecular Biology. Published.
  • Oppenheim, S., Rosenfeld, J., and DeSalle, R (2016). Electronic annotation reveals a novel functional category for Anophelinae-P. falciparum interactions. BMC Genomics. Accepted with minor revision.
  • Oppenheim, S., Feindt, W., DeSalle, R., and Goldstein, P. Comparative transcriptomics of Papapeima stembores. In prep.
  • Oppenheim, S., Feindt, W., Goldstein, P, Murray, B., and DeSalle, R. Comparative transcriptomics of Heliothinae moths. In prep.

 

Grants and funding

  • I was awarded research grants from The Explorers Club (NYC) and CIES/Fulbright to support the S. American fieldwork portion of my research project.
  • I received a Helmsley Fellowship to attend "Programming for Biology" at CSHL.
  • Along with my REU student, I received a BIO-OCE REU Mentor-Student Travel Scholarship.
